headline: The Bull Case For Uber Technologies (UBER) Could Change Following Nationwide Kroger Grocery Rollout Onto Uber Apps
summary: In mid-January 2026, Uber Technologies and The Kroger Co. rolled out nearly 2,700 Kroger Family of Companies stores onto the Uber Eats, Uber, and Postmates apps, giving customers nationwide access to full-store grocery assortments with on-demand and same-day delivery. This expansion deepens Uber’s presence in grocery delivery while reinforcing its role as a broader everyday shopping platform rather than only a restaurant marketplace. Next, we’ll examine how this nationwide Kroger rollout...

headline: Jim Cramer on American Electric Power: “One of My Favorite Utilities for Multiple Years”
summary: American Electric Power Company, Inc. (NASDAQ:AEP) is one of the stocks Jim Cramer recently looked at. headline: Why Uber Is Letting AI Use “Common Sense” in Customer Service
summary: Dara Khosrowshahi, Uber CEO, speaks with WSJ Leadership Institute President Alan Murray about why Uber is scrapping rigid rule-based systems and empowering AI to make judgment calls. Khosrowshahi says that AI guided by context and “common sense” can deliver a better customer service experience rather than sticking to a rigid rule book.

headline: Uber CEO Warns The 'Biggest Factor' In AV Growth Is Affordability, As Significant Scaling Could Take 10-20 Years
summary: Uber Technologies Inc. (NYSE:UBER) CEO Dara Khosrowshahi highlighted the key factors influencing the growth of autonomous vehicles. High Costs Slow AV Adoption Speaking at the World Economic Forum, Davos, on Tuesday, Khosrowshahi emphasized the critical role of affordability in the expansion of autonomous vehicles. He noted that the current cost of these vehicles is “well over” $100,000. The CEO added that many autonomous vehicles on the road today lack the computing capacity required to meet sa

headline: Should Israel’s Opening to App-Based Ride Hailing Require Action From Lyft (LYFT) Investors?
summary: An Israeli ministerial committee has approved a bill that would allow ride-hailing platforms such as Lyft and Uber to operate in Israel, creating a formal regulatory framework for app-based services aimed at increasing transportation supply and lowering costs; the proposal now awaits full parliamentary approval following this past committee decision. For Lyft, the move is material because it opens the door to a new national market where regulatory access has historically been restricted,...
